awd_abstract_narration:
Digital forensics is a rapidly growing branch of forensics that focuses on the recovery and investigation of data found in digital devices. It is now a major part of many criminal and civil investigations and its tools are used by local, state, and Federal law enforcement agencies with increasing frequency.  Digital forensics education programs are needed to increase the size of the technical workforce to meet the needs of the nation.  The project focuses on the development of undergraduate programs modeled on the standardized curricula proposed by NSA, DHS, Security Centers for Academic Excellence, ACM, and IEEE. It contributes to the creation of resources and educational materials for use in academic programs, distance learning, multi-disciplinary, and multi-institutional programs that meet the evolving standards.

The field of digital forensics depends on many disciplines and skills including evidence collection, preservation, and presentation as well as forensic preparation.  The Information Trust Institute education team involves cross-field collaboration and includes the Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Business and Accounting, Criminal Justice, Law, and Educational Assessment experts that are needed for this type of curriculum development.  In addition, the Institute has research findings in many digital forensics application areas (supercomputing, clouds, cyber infrastructures for transportation, power, health, and mobile computing) that are being integrated into this comprehensive multi-disciplinary educational program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The Program in Digital Forensics team has developed a new undergraduate educational curriculum in digital forensics in order to address a national shortage of trained cyber-security professionals. The multidisciplinary two-course sequence of materials is available to interested educational institutions. The materials include both lectures (PowerPoint decks and instructor handbooks) and labs (datasets and instructor handbooks) and cover key aspects of computer forensics, file system and operating system forensics, networking forensics, mobile device and mobile network forensics, reverse engineering, malware, timeline analysis, incident response, database forensics, tool validation, criminal justice, law, criminal psychology, business and accounting fraud, and forensics in digital archives. This grant also supported the organization of four annual International Workshops on Digital Forensics Curriculum Standards (DFCS) from 2013 through 2016. Each DFCS workshop focused on a specific theme and brought together leading digital forensics practitioners and educators for discussions, networking, and brainstorming that proved to be highly productive in advertising the availability of the curriculum materials, as well as in advancing the digital forensics community’s conversation about how to train future digital forensics experts.

Broader Impacts: The curriculum resources created have already been used multiple times in University of Illinois courses, and will be usable as the basis for other institutions’ academic programs, distance learning, and multidisciplinary, multi-institutional programs that meet evolving standards. The curricula were developed to meet the needs of both universities and two-year colleges, and a K-12 outreach program has been translating the educational materials and program to levels suitable for a wider audience. Much of the material has been made available online (on a password-protected secure site) and shared with other institutions. The digital forensics curriculum standard that was developed is expected to be widely applicable, meeting real-world industry needs while accommodating the funding and personnel limitations of many academic institutions.


Last Modified: 10/07/2016
Modified by: Roy H Campbell
